note_text: OPERATIVE NARRATIVE: Therapeutic whole lung lavage. The procedure was initiated on the left lung following double-lumen intubation. After the instillation of 6 L of saline, the patient manifested refractory hypoxemia despite recruitment maneuvers. The procedure was aborted to ensure patient safety. Residual fluid was evacuated, and two-lung ventilation resumed. The patient was transferred to the intensive care unit for ongoing respiratory support.

note_text: Mr. Foster underwent an attempted left whole lung lavage for his PAP. We placed a double-lumen tube and began the washing process. Unfortunately, after using about 6 liters of fluid, his oxygen levels dropped dangerously low. We made the decision to stop the procedure immediately, drain the remaining fluid, and transfer him to the ICU while keeping him on the ventilator.

note_text:
PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Pediatric rigid bronchoscopy with foreign body retrieval.
CLINICAL SUMMARY: This 2-year-old male presented with findings consistent with foreign body aspiration. Rigid bronchoscopy revealed an organic foreign body, identified as a peanut fragment, obstructing the right middle lobe bronchus. The object was successfully extracted using optical alligator forceps. The airway was subsequently cleared of secretions. There was a transient desaturation event which resolved promptly.

note_text:
OPERATIVE REPORT: Rigid bronchoscopy for foreign body removal.
FINDINGS: A brightly colored plastic foreign body was visualized impacting the left mainstem bronchus. 
PROCEDURE: The object was engaged and extracted in a single piece utilizing optical grasping forceps. Re-inspection of the tracheobronchial tree confirmed complete removal with no residual fragments. The patient tolerated the procedure well.

note_text:
PROCEDURE: Flexible bronchoscopy with foreign body removal.
CLINICAL CONTEXT: The patient aspirated a dental crown during a dental procedure. 
FINDINGS: The metallic foreign body was localized to the right lower lobe basal segment. 
INTERVENTION: Under fluoroscopic guidance, the object was secured with flexible alligator forceps and successfully retrieved. Inspection of the bronchial mucosa revealed mild erythema but no perforation.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Recurrent unilateral pleural effusion suspicious for malignancy
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Large recurrent left pleural effusion with compressive atelectasis
registry_entry.anesthesia_agents: Midazolam, fentanyl, local lidocaine and bupivacaine
registry_entry.pleural_thoracoscopy_findings: Diffuse parietal pleural nodularity and studding suspicious for malignancy
registry_entry.bronch_specimen_tests: Pleural biopsies for histology, cytology, flow cytometry
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Suspected malignant pleural effusion; final pleural biopsy results pending
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Daily CXRs; remove chest tube once output low and lung fully expanded

note_text:
PROCEDURE: Medical thoracoscopy with pleural biopsy and pleurodesis.
FINDINGS: Thoracoscopic inspection of the left hemithorax revealed diffuse nodularity and studding of the parietal pleura, highly suspicious for malignancy. Approximately 1.5 L of straw-colored effusion was evacuated. 
INTERVENTION: Multiple targeted parietal pleural biopsies were obtained. Following complete drainage, a talc slurry was instilled to achieve pleurodesis.

Procedure: Med Thoracoscopy + Talc
Steps:
1. MAC/Local.
2. Trocar in 6th ICS.

4. Saw nodules, took biopsies.
5. Put in talc slurry.
6. Chest tube placed.
Plan: Admit.

note_text: We performed a medical thoracoscopy on Mr. Turner to diagnose and treat his recurrent fluid buildup. We drained 1.5 liters of fluid and found several nodules on the lining of the lung, which we biopsied. To prevent the fluid from coming back, we performed a talc pleurodesis. He will stay in the hospital with a chest tube for a few days.

PROCEDURE: Ultrasound-guided therapeutic thoracentesis.
NARRATIVE: The right hemithorax was scanned, identifying a locatable pocket of fluid in the 8th intercostal space. Under local anesthesia, a catheter was introduced and 900 mL of clear serous fluid was aspirated. The patient tolerated the procedure without complication.

note_text:
PROCEDURE: Medical thoracoscopy with talc poudrage and placement of indwelling pleural catheter.
FINDINGS: Thoracoscopy revealed extensive parietal pleural implants. 1.8 L of serosanguinous fluid was evacuated. 
INTERVENTION: Talc poudrage was insufflated for pleurodesis. Additionally, a tunneled indwelling pleural catheter was placed to ensure long-term drainage capability. 
DISPOSITION: The patient will be admitted for overnight observation.

note_text: Mr. Hall underwent a procedure to manage his malignant fluid buildup. We performed a thoracoscopy, drained 1.8 liters of fluid, and sprayed talc to seal the lung. We also placed a permanent tunneled catheter to allow for drainage at home if the fluid comes back. He will stay overnight for monitoring.

Procedure: Pleuroscopy with chemical sclerosis and tunnelled drain insertion.

Outcome: Dual modality management established.
